nodes.text: A land price bubble can arise even when observed housing rent-to-price ratios do not vanish (are stationary); therefore non-vanishing housing yields do not rule out land bubbles
Distinguishing pure land rent from housing-structure rent is essential because the aggregate housing rent-to-price ratio can be stationary while pure land rent contains a bubble

Method: Construct a two-period overlapping generations model with consumption good and housing service, Cobb-Douglas preferences, unit supply of land, and a representative firm producing housing from construction material and land

Assumption: Production function F(M,X) is homogeneous of degree one, differentiable, concave, with positive partials and an Inada-type condition lim_{M->0} (FX/FM)(M,1)=0; construction material equals consumption good and housing fully depreciates
Equilibrium conditions: young maximize utility subject to budget, firm maximizes profit rt F(M,X)-M-Dt X, commodity and housing market clearing, and land market clearing x_t=1
Proposition 1 (Result): The aggregate rent-to-price ratio r_t h_t / P_t is constant and equals beta_h / beta_o under the model's equilibrium
Proposition 2 (Result): There exists a unique equilibrium characterized by first-order conditions and budget shares, and a land bubble exists if and only if the sum over t of FX/F (M_t,1) is finite
Derivation: Land price equals P_t = beta_o e_t from Cobb-Douglas expenditure shares and budget constraints
Derivation: Profit maximization implies 1 = r_t F_M(M_t,1) and D_t = r_t F_X(M_t,1), and dividend yield D_t / P_t = (beta_h / beta_o) (F_X / F)(M_t,1)

Proposition 3 (Result): With CES production with elasticity of substitution sigma>1, a land bubble exists iff the sum over t of e_t^{1/sigma -1} is finite; hence balanced growth (e_t growing geometrically) implies inevitable land bubbles

Conclusion: Empirical dismissal of land or housing bubbles based solely on stationary aggregate price-rent ratios is flawed; empirical work must separate pure land rent from structure rent to detect land bubbles
Context: Some empirical researchers and reviewers argue bubbles are absent because dividend or rent yields appear stationary, motivating the present counterexample
Limitation: The model is a minimal two-period OLG with perishable housing and deterministic environment; these simplifications may limit direct empirical mapping
Claim: The Bubble Characterization Lemma implies an asset exhibits a bubble iff the sum over time of dividend yield Dt/Pt is finite, linking analytical dividend-yield behavior to bubble existence
